description.narrative: Conserving a source population of tigers - monitoring tigers and other wildlife in Bhutan's Royal Manas National Park

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

description.narrative: "The purpose of this proposal is to establish a measurable increase in tactical protection, patrolling and monitoring in Bhutans Royal Manas National Park for tiger conservation. This will be done by improving law enforcement in RMNP by implementing a rigorous advanced patrolling protocol that is adaptively managed through SMART law enforcement monitoring software and establishing a foundation of effective protection that enables RMNP to achieve accreditation under the protection portion of CA|TS...Specifically, this will be done by: 1. conducting a threat analysis to identify and analyze key factors that endanger the valuable assets of RMNP; 2. training and equipping frontline staff to document and record information using standard uniform data protocols; 3. training one data officer and project officer on the use of SMART law enforcement monitoring protocols and analysis of outputs generated to enable implementation of adaptive measures; 4. setting up a central control station and pilot the law enforcement monitoring in an area of the park; and 5. setting up a checklist as a foundation for a protection strategy, which will be included in the main management plan/system for CA|TS.."

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Capacity Building to crack down on Tiger Poaching and Trade in Bhutan

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to build Forest Protection and Surveillance Unit (FPSU) trainer capacity in law enforcement monitoring tools, intelligence tools and standard anti-poaching ranger trainings as per the IUCN standards for national roll out. The project will support capacity building of FPSU and divisional field staff to train others on SMART and standard anti-poaching ranger training, as well as to best utilize the Bhutan Forestry Enforcement Database (BhuFED), and integrate SMART with BhuFED as well as increase national awareness on law enforcement tools and trainings available in Bhutan through FPSU.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Examining the attitudes of local people toward elephants in a human-elephant conflict in southern Bhutan.

description.narrative: This project will study the attitudes of local people towards Asian elephants in a high human-elephant conflict (HEC) area of southern Bhutan and will help to understand the types and extent of HEC in this region. Project activities include: 1) questionnaire and survey design, planning, development, and pre-testing of the survey instrument; 2) survey of agriculturalists in the conflict zone; 3) comparison of the number and intensity of HEC events with and without HEC mitigation (electric fences) tools in use; 4) provision of elephant conservation education and awareness programs to youth and farmers in the conflict area. The results from this study will be used to inform land use planners and conservationists to better plan, design, and implement HEC mitigation actions and ultimately conserve Asian elephants in Bhutan.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Examining livestock depredation by tiger and its impact on farmers livelihood in Bhutans Jigme Dorji National Park

description.narrative: Human-wildlife conflict in Jigme Dorji National Park (JDNP), Bhutan, is costing farmers additional expenses, and possible personal injury. This project aims to examine the extent and magnitude of conflict between tiger and agro-pastoralists and propose a measure that may reduce the conflicts. The project will also conduct awareness programs on significance of conserving tiger in forest ecosystem in the park and neighboring regions. Project objectives include the following: (1) Examining livestock depredation by tiger and assessing its impact on farmer's livelihood; (2) Evaluating peoples perceptions and attitudes towards conservation of tigers; (3) Raising the awareness of the role of the tiger in forest ecosystem amongst inhabitants of JDNP through education programs and the distribution of educational materials; and, (4) Groundwork is laid for establishing an effective network of citizens to monitor and protect tiger, their prey species, and habitat amongst farmers in the lowland areas of JDNP.

title.narrative: Conservation of Endangered Royal Bengal Tiger (Panthera tigris) in South Central Bhutan.

description.narrative: Predator- prey relationship for management of tiger and its prey is poorly known in the south central region of Bhutan. Human-tiger conflict is also a serious issue in this due to depredation on livestock. Zhemgang Forest Division in particular is giving priority to tiger conservation activities via natural and social research activities. The project is planned to understand tiger-prey relationship to help with tiger management in this region, and, evaluate peoples perception and attitude towards tiger conservation. As part of the education program, awareness of tiger conservation will be imparted to farmers and youth within conflict areas. The findings from the research will be useful baseline information to conservationists and planners, to design and implement right management for tiger, its prey and for mitigation measures to minimize human-tiger conflicts in near future. Objectives include: (1) To assess the prey population structure and prey preferences of Bengal tiger; (2)To evaluate the extent of Human-tiger conflict and peoples attitude towards tiger conservation; and, (3) To provide tiger conservation education to youth and farmers.

title.narrative: SECURING BREEDING AND POPULATION DISPERSAL OF ROYAL BENGAL TIGER THROUGH SAFEGUARDING BIOLOGICAL CORRIDOR 4 IN BHUTAN

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SECURE THE BREEDING HABITAT AND POPULATION DISPERSAL OF TIGERS IN BIOLOGICAL CORRIDOR 4. THE PROJECT WILL HELP PREPARE A MANAGEMENT PLAN TO FOCUS ON PROTECTING TIGER HABITAT, STRENGTHEN SMART (SPATIAL MONITORING AND REPORTING TOOL) PATROLLING, AND ENHANCE COMMUNITY AWARENESS ABOUT TIGER CONSERVATION.

title.narrative: SECURING BREEDING AND POPULATION DISPERSAL OF ROYAL BENGAL TIGER THROUGH SAFEGUARDING BIOLOGICAL CORRIDOR 4 IN BHUTAN

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to secure the breeding habitat and population dispersal of tigers in Biological Corridor 4. The project will help prepare a management plan to focus on protecting tiger habitat, strengthen SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) patrolling, and enhance community awareness about tiger conservation.
